description.narrative: Strengthening Multi-Sectoral Management of Critical Landscapes_SAMOA

title.narrative: Strenghtening Multi-Sectoral Management of Critical Landscape (SMSMCL) - MTE
Strengthening Multi-Sectoral Management of Critical Land
Strengthening Multi-Sectoral Management of Critical Land
Strengthening Multi-Sectoral Management of Critical Land

description.narrative: Strengthening Multi-Sectoral Management of Critical Landscapes_SAMOA
Environment - policy, planning and administration

To strengthen local capacities, incentives and actions for integrated landscape management to reduce land degradation and greenhouse gas emissions and to promote conservation whilst enhancing sustainable local livelihoods
Area under increased vegetative cover

comment.narrative: 0 ha

24,430 ha
[This figure is based on 18,930 ha of changes in current agricultural land-use practices and at least 5,000 hectares of degraded lands restored through community activities and further 500 hectares will be forests]
0 ha

description.narrative: Area under forest cover (no net loss due to landuse conversion) under effective management

comment.narrative: To be reported on at MTR

description.narrative: Increase of agriculture income and consumption per household as a consequence of increased productivity of land

comment.narrative: US$2692 on average (national)
5000 households’ incomes increase by 10% on average by project end through increased land productivity
0 household with increase in income

description.narrative: Total amount of CO2 equivalent greenhouse gas emission avoided, and sequestered at the target sites due to effective application of SLM good practices

comment.narrative: Total national emissions from AFOLU 135.37, Gg CO2-e (2007).
Avoided emission of 689333 CO2-eq for 4 years and sequestration of store additionally 10,755 tCO2eq.
No Emission at this stage

description.narrative: Communities and farmers are able to undertake and benefit from integrated land and water management on their traditionally owned lands.
1.       Number of certified organic farmers/farms

comment.narrative: 606 certified currently exist; 345 in Savaii & 261 in Upolu
A 30% increase in number of households engaged in organic farming or more ecological farming
No household/No farmer as of yet getting organic certification

description.narrative: 2.       Increased density and diversity of native tree species in cyclone damaged landscapes around Apia covering 3314 ha

comment.narrative: With recent damage by TC Evans, baseline will be determined when project start.
At least 50% increase forest cover in a landscape
Once the recruitment of the GIS specialist is finalized and on-board the project, the baseline will be determined and established.

description.narrative: 3.       Area of natural forests, riverine areas and wetlands under protection and management in the production landscape under community landuse plans (forest and tree cover maintenance; maintenance of wetlands; no net increase of agricultural land under mono cropping)

comment.narrative: By the end of the project, at least 55000 ha will be under integrated landscape management outside KBAs

- 0 ha under integrated landscape management outside KBAs.
- Meantime initial consultation and discussion within the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment as part of project planning to safeguard a critical Apia Watershed Basin to come under the State forest and watershed protection promoting integrated landscape management. This integrated landscape management inclusive of all villages within the Apia Watershed Basin would be part of the community commitment to forest protection and conservation that will be featured in their Sustainable Village Development Plan.

description.narrative: 4.       Number of farmer households adopting at least one or more soil / water management and conservation practices on agricultural lands

comment.narrative: There are 10790 households in the target area of the project, but with limited soil and water conservation activities
At least 5000 households will be adopting soil management and conservation practices in their land by the end of the project covering at least 18000 ha
0 household

description.narrative: 5.       Increased water quality as a consequence of enhanced watershed management and water source protection

comment.narrative: Water quality at sampled sites (3 major sites) shows confirmed incidences of E.coli presence exceeding national standards

At least 50% of the project sites report on increased water quality by the end of the project – including E. coli levels within national standards; and additional parameters of nutrient loads (such as nitrogen) are also within acceptable international standards

- 0% of water quality improvement
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

description.narrative: 6.       Per cent of Livestock relocated to optimal grazing areas away from critical riparian areas

comment.narrative: Estimated 30000 livestock in target areas, covering 5000 ha
At least 50% relocated, covering 2500 ha

- 0% relocation with no ha
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

description.narrative: 7.       Number of integrated participatory village level SLM plans

comment.narrative: No village plans incorporating SLM
At least 50 villages have developed plans integrating SLM with the participation of 15000 community member including men, women and young

- No village with Integrating SLM Plan
- Progress to date including workshop preparation with key stakeholders eg. Ministry of Women, Social Development in preparation for review of Community/Village Development Plan to ensure integration of SLM.
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

description.narrative: 8.       Number of community members that report on increased knowledge and capacity on SLM

comment.narrative: No reports on knowledge on SLM
At least 40% of the communities are able to report on increased knowledge on SLM through access to national SLM system, audio-video materials and trainings

- No report at this stage on knowledge of SLM
- Progress to date include recruitment process of an expert in designing Sustainable Agriculture and SLM awareness materials to assist with community training on SLM/Agriculture best practices.
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

description.narrative: Strengthened national enabling environment to promote integrated landscape management through local households and communities.
9.       Soil management and conservation manual targeting local communities in local language

comment.narrative: No soil management and conservation manual
By the end of year 1 a Soil management and conservation manual developed including SLM practices for agriculture, forestry and water resources management
Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

description.narrative: 10.       Number of national policies and plans that support for inter-sectoral and partnership approach to promote community based SLM

comment.narrative: A number of policies and plans to support SLM (see section 1.5 of the project document) but inter-sectoral approach is weak

Land Resource management legislation developed and national landuse policy updated
Agriculture Sector Plan 2011-2016 strengthen to mainstream SLM approaches and management practices
policies on mining (including sand mining) strengthened or developed
formal guidelines for sustainable land management under village development plans under PUMA Act developed

- No policy review to date
- Progress to date include preparation works with the Ministry of MNRE through the Land Management Division for policy review of existing land resource management policy and legislation to ensure SLM is incorporated and strengthened across all levels eg. policy, operation and implementation, monitoring
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

description.narrative: 11.      Increased capacities for INRM as measured by an increase in the score of the GEF LD Tracking Tool Enhanced cross-sector enabling environment for integrated landscape management

comment.narrative:
- 0
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

description.narrative: 12.       Coordination mechanism in place to ensure multi-sector approach to SLM in line with National Environment management Strategy

comment.narrative: No coordination mechanisms for SLM

By the end of the project a formal institutional coordination mechanism has been established including all relevant ministries to ensure integration of SLM in all sectors to manage multiuse landscapes through combined efforts, shared technical resources

- No coordination mechanism in place
- Progress to date include the drafting of the Institutional Coordinated Mechanism for the Project to ensure multi-sectoral approach to SLM.
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

description.narrative: 13.       Increased involvement of private sector, civil society and others in promoting SLM in partnership with the government.

comment.narrative: SFA and WIBDI – NGOs assisting communities with projects that are SLM compatible.
By Year 4, the number of NGOs and private partners in SLM is increased by 200%.

- NGOs and CSOs such as Samoa Farmer Association (SFA), Women in Business (WIB) and Matua-le-oo (METI), Samoa Conservation Society (CSO) and SUNGO have been consulted and have shown interest with partnership to include SLM into their work. Some of these NGO for instance WIB and METI has already worked with the community through training of farmers into some sort of SLM approach.
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to the actual implementation of this component in the 4th Quarter 2015 once training materials have been finalized.

description.narrative: 14.       National SLM information system in line with information system for national Environment Management Strategy

comment.narrative: No SLM information system
By Year 4 an SLM information System will be established and managed by MNRE

- No SLM Information system established yet
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

description.narrative: 15.       Number of government staff who have completed new training of trainers short term courses provided by USP on SLM, tailored for Samoa and including carbon accounting from LULUCF

comment.narrative: No SLM training currently available at USP for government staff
By the end of the project, at least 100 staff from MNRE, MAF, MWCSC have completed the SLM training at USP

- 0 staff training on SLM
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

description.narrative: 16.       Number of long term courses institutionalized in USP to degree students on SLM

comment.narrative: No SLM courses available at University for undergraduate students
By the end of the project, at least 1 SLM long term course has been institutionalized at USP

- No SLM course designed at USP as of yet
- Project will report on the progress on this particular component (target) once we come to this stage of the implementation.

title.narrative: Enhancing the Resilience of Tourism-reliant Communities

description.narrative: Enhancing the Resilience of Tourism-reliant Communities to Climate Change Risks

title.narrative: Enhancing the Resilience of Tourism-reliant Communities
Enhancing the Resilience of Tourism-reliant Communities
Enhancing the Resilience of Tourism-reliant Communities
Enhancing the Resilience of Tourism-reliant Communities
Enhancing the Resilience of Tourism-reliant Communities
Enhancing the Resilience of Tourism-reliant Communities
Enhancing the Resilience of Tourism-reliant Communities
Enhancing the Resilience of Tourism-reliant Communities

description.narrative: UNDAF Outcomes: • OUTCOME 1: Equitable Economic Growth & Poverty Reduction. • OUTCOME 2: Good Governance and Human Rights • OUTCOME 3: Sustainable Environmental Management
populated place
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

Increase the resilience of the tourism sector of Samoa through mainstreaming climate risks into tourism-related policy processes which guide the implementation of adaptation actions by tourism operators and tourism reliant communities.

Capacity perception index of STA disaggregated by gender; AMAT 2.2.2) (1=no capacity built
2=initial awareness raised
3=substantial training in practical application
4=knowledge effectively transferred
5=ability to apply or disseminate knowledge demonstrated)

comment.narrative: Capacity of STA is currently rated at 2-3.
By the end of the project the capacity is 4-5.

At the end of this review period, the rated capacity of the STA has progressed to 3 – 4. This is due to the involvement of staff in the project workshops carried out during the reported period. The Participatory Three (3) Dimensional Model workshops conducted during the formulation of the TDA Management Plans brought STA staff to learn and participate in this key part of the project.

description.narrative: % of tourism operators who invest and implement sustainable adaptation measures to enhance their resilience.

comment.narrative: Tourism operators are not investing in sustainable adaptation measures, but instead in quick and unsustainable measures to cope with climate risks
At least 75% of all tourism operators in the 6 targeted TDAs have invested and implemented sustainable adaptation measures

An approximate of 30% of operators in the TDAs are investing in sustainable adaptation measures. Operators have learned of the importance of replanting initiatives. Manase operators for instance had not opted for a rock seawall for protection through gained knowledge that this will speed up erosion resulting in total loss of their beach. Villages in the TDAs have also reported that sand-mining has been banned for commercial use and monitored by the village council and are supported by some of the village bylaws for the villages who have completed these.
Furthermore, the beach fale operator at Satuiatua which is one of the TDAs on Savaii has been advocating in their village to stop the removal of the beach rocks along the shore.

description.narrative: Climate change adaptation mainstreamed into tourism-related policy instruments and public-private partnerships
# of Management Plans developed and operationalized

comment.narrative: Climate resilient management plans are currently not in place
By the end of the project, at least 6 climate resilient management plans have been developed and operationalized per TDA, involving at least 20 villages in total.
The project has received 6 draft TDA Management Plans from the Water Technology company. The project is currently undertaking its first review.

description.narrative: % of tourism operators in targeted TDAs apply new guidelines for climate resilient actions

comment.narrative: No guidelines exist for effective no-regrets adaptation measures to increase resilience of tourism operators and there is a history of little application of guidelines is commonly low
By the end of the project, at least 75% of the targeted tourism operators apply the issued guidelines
The Guidelines are currently being drafted and hope foreseen to be finalized once received by mid July 2015.

description.narrative: # of tourism operators that gain access to financial products for climate resilient actions

comment.narrative: Tourism operators do not access financial products for climate resilient actions
By the end of the project, at least 15 operators have successfully gained access to financial products for climate resilient actions

At the moment, the Small Grants Scheme Guidelines are being drafted and finalised to roll out the funds for climate resilient activities. Informal agreement and discussions took place with the PSSF (Private Sector Support Facility) for channelling funds in respect of environmental safeguards. A Small Grant facilitator will be hired by the project to streamline the process of channelling grants and implementation of climate resilient actions. Operators are eagerly awaiting the opportunity through the Small Grants component of the project to assist with the climate resilient projects.

description.narrative: Increased adaptive capacity to climate change and disaster risks of tourism-reliant communites
Number and type of risk reduction activities introduced in tourism reliant communities (AMAT 2.3.1.1)

comment.narrative: No Operators with Business plans which incorporate climate smart risk assessment & planning
At least five risk reduction activities have been introduced across the 9 villages in the 6 TDAs

At the moment, the Manase Detailed Design for Beach Replenishment and control for coastal protection is currently underway which will benefit the whole village of Manase. Beach fale operators at Saleapaga in south east Upolu have also with the assistance of other line projects completed an evacuation route that will benefit the whole village of Saleapaga.

description.narrative: % of women and men in tourism reliant communities trained in climate risk reduction

comment.narrative: Initial awareness raising activities have taken place in the project area under the PPG phase, but no systematic training has been provided on
By the end of the project at least 50% of the women and 50% of the men of the targeted communities has been trained in climate risk reduction

An integrated training program for the TDAs targeted has been recommended under the TDA Management Plans to be part of the wider Samoa Tourism Support Programme (STSP). The CLEWS component of this project will also hold workshops and trainings for the TDAs. Introductory information was provided through the Tourism Cyclone Recovery Programme (TCRP) Financial Risk Management assessment on geo hazards and climate futures. Women and men have been consistently equally present at the workshops conducted. The P3D model workshops, held in each TDA to inform the Management plans, have also served to train communities on the most threatening climate risks with specific reference to each particular geographical context.

description.narrative: % of targeted tourism reliant communities that have adopted climate resilient livelihoods

comment.narrative: Apart from some ad-hoc measures individuals are taking, none of the targeted communities have climate resilient livelihoods
By the end of the project at least 80% of the targeted communities have adopted climate resilient livelihoods

Targeted TDAs are adopting climate resilient livelihoods and are starting with relocation of some of the key infrastructures in the safe zones such as the ones on the south eastern side of Upolu (Saleapaga and Lalomanu), as a result of information received through the project. Some of the operators at Manase have started to move some of their assets further away from the beach. Plantation tours, visit to nearby attractions including cultural and natural sites such as the Mt Matavanu crater, caves, pools and village walks have also been considered as key activities for tourists to complement the beach experience.

The Samoa One UN YEP project is responding to the request from the Government of Samoa to assist in addressing youth unemployment. Its main objective is to assist youth to develop knowledge and skills needed to enter the formal labour market.
